class  Util::GlobalId
 Class for representing a global identifier of the distributed processusGlobal Identifier values are segmented in order to reserve special name for some special meaning. The unsigned integer on 32 bits are organized as following: b31|b30|...|b1|b0 where bi is the i-th bit. b31 is the high order bit. Bits b31|b30, if non nul represent special values.

  • b31|b30 = 0|0: user defined values between 0 and 2^30-1 (1073741823 values)
  • b31|b30|b29= 1|1|1: special values
    • ALL_SITE: all other bits are =1
    • NO_SITE: all other bits are =0
  • b31|b30|b29= 1|1|0: for identifying checkpoint servers
  • b31|b30|b29= 1|0|0: for identifying temporary name using counter
  • b31|b30|b29= 1|0|1: for identifying temporary name using hash value.
More...

Pointer

Type for a global pointer

Util::Pointer is the type to represent a generic pointer into one of the address space of a set of process on differents architecture. The size in bits of the Util::Pointer is at least enough to represent any of the LocalPointer of the architecture. The current implementation is to represent any pointer as a 64 bits long integer. Thus a remote pointer is close to an 64 bits integer.

Author:
T. Gautier
